question: 6 (b)
statement_html:
Let t be the time (in hours) it takes for a cell division to occur. Suppose t is a continuous random variable on the interval \(0 \leq t \leq 1\) (i.e. the cells always divide in less than 1 hour), with probability density

\(\displaystyle p(t) = C(\sqrt{t}-t)\)

b) Find the probability that cell division occurs in less than 30 minutes.
statement_latex:
Let \emph{t} be the time (in hours) it takes for a cell division to
occur. Suppose \emph{t} is a continuous random variable on the interval
$0 \leq t \leq 1$ (i.e. the cells always divide in less than 1 hour),
with probability density

$\displaystyle p(t) = C(\sqrt{t}-t)$

b) Find the probability that cell division occurs in less than 30
minutes.
statement_raw:
Let ''t'' be the time (in hours) it takes for a cell division to occur. Suppose ''t'' is a continuous random variable on the interval <math> 0 \leq t \leq 1 </math> (i.e. the cells always divide in less than 1 hour), with probability density 

<math> \displaystyle p(t) = C(\sqrt{t}-t)</math>

b) Find the probability that cell division occurs in less than 30 minutes.
